title: Disability Benefits Explained: SSDI vs SSI
seoTitle: SSDI vs SSI: Disability Help Guide
summary: Confused about disability benefits? This guide explains the difference between Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI) and Supplemental Security Income (SSI), who qualifies, and how to apply.

body.raw:
## Introduction If you or a loved one are living with a disability, you may qualify for monthly financial support from the federal government ‚Äî but many people don‚Äôt understand the difference between **SSDI** and **SSI**. These two programs offer disability benefits, but they have very different eligibility rules. Knowing which one applies to your situation can help you get the support you need faster. *** ## What‚Äôs the Difference Between SSDI and SSI? Both SSDI and SSI are run by the **Social Security Administration (SSA)**, but they serve different people: **SSDI (Social Security Disability Insurance):** - For disabled workers who have a qualifying work history - Based on the number of work credits and disability status - Monthly benefit varies depending on your past income **SSI (Supplemental Security Income):** - For low-income individuals who are aged, blind, or disabled - Based on financial need (income and assets) - Maximum monthly benefit for an individual in 2025 is $943 You can't receive both full SSDI and full SSI at the same time, but some people do qualify for partial benefits from each. ## Who Qualifies for SSDI? To get SSDI, you must: 1. Have a **disability expected to last at least one year or result in death** 2. Have **earned enough work credits** (based on your age and job history) 3. Be **unable to perform substantial gainful work** SSDI is an insurance program ‚Äî you "pay into it" by working and paying Social Security taxes. ## Who Qualifies for SSI? To get SSI, you must: 1. Be **age 65 or older**, **blind**, or **disabled** 2. Have **very limited income and resources** 3. Be a **U.S. citizen or qualified immigrant** SSI is a need-based program and does not require a work history. ## How to Apply for Disability Benefits You can apply for both programs: 1. **Online at SSA.gov** 2. **By calling 1-800-772-1213** 3. **At your local Social Security office** The application will ask for medical records, income info, work history, and proof of disability. It can take 3‚Äì6 months (or longer) to get a decision. If you‚Äôre denied, don‚Äôt give up ‚Äî you can appeal and many applicants win benefits on appeal. People who qualify for SSI often also qualify for [Medicaid](https://www.medicaid.gov/) and [SNAP food assistance](./wic-vs-snap-what-s-the-difference-and-can-you-get-both). ## Tips for Applicants - **Document everything**: Keep records of doctor visits, test results, and medication - **Start early**: Apply as soon as you become unable to work ‚Äî delays can cost you months of payments - **Get help**: Legal aid or disability advocates can assist you if your claim is denied > üí° **Tip:** Many people wrongly assume they can‚Äôt qualify because they ‚Äúhaven‚Äôt worked enough‚Äù ‚Äî but SSI exists for those with no work history. Don‚Äôt self-reject. *** ###### References
